Article.Abstract: We have investigated the vaccine potential of two peptides derived from the 6-kDa early secretory antigenic target (ESAT)-6 antigen in the mouse model of tuberculosis. The peptides were both strongly immunogenic in B6CBAF1 (H-2b,k) mice and primed recall responses of the same intensity after immunization. However, both tuberculosis infection and immunization with ESAT-6 resulted in responses focused towards ESAT-61-20. Multiple antigen peptide constructs as well as free peptides were emulsified with dimethyl dioctadecylammonium bromide/monophosphoryl lipid A/IL-2 and tested as experimental vaccines in an i.v. and aerosol model of tuberculosis in mice. The peptide were highly immunogenic and induced cellular responses of the same magnitude. However, only vaccines based on the subdominant ESAT-651-70 epitope promoted significant levels of protective immunity and the level of protection was equivalent to that achieved with ESAT-6 and BCG. These findings demonstrate the potential of peptide-based vaccines against tuberculosis and indicate that there is not direct correlation between the hierarchy of response to naturally processed peptides and their ability to induce protective immunity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Article.ArticleTitle: Efficient protection against Mycobacterium tuberculosis by vaccination with a single subdominant epitope from the ESAT-6 antigen.
Article.Affiliations: Department of TB Immunology, Statens Serum Institute, Copenhagen, Denmark.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Bacterial;BCG Vaccine;Bacterial Proteins;ESAT-6 protein, Mycobacterium tuberculosis;Epitopes, T-Lymphocyte;Immunodominant Epitopes;Peptides
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Antigens, Bacterial(immunology); BCG Vaccine(immunology); Bacterial Proteins; Disease Models, Animal; Epitopes, T-Lymphocyte(immunology); Immunodominant Epitopes(immunology); Mice; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Molecular Sequence Data; Mycobacterium tuberculosis(immunology); Peptides(immunology); Tuberculosis(immunology; prevention & control); Vaccination

AssayInformation.AssayComments: In similar studies, IL-5 was found to be produced in extremely low amounts. Blocking with a monoclonal anitbody against CD8 had no effect on the size of the responses.

Mice were infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis for 1 month or 7 months, and positive dose-responses were shown at both time points. Responses were similar to those against ESAT-6 protein. Purification studies showed the response was CD4-specific. In parallel studies of a second ESAT-6 epitope (51-70), this epitope was shown to be dominant. Similar results were found in ELISPOT assays 2-4 weeks post infection.

When this epitope was co-administered with a second ESAT-6 epitope (51-70), the responses were biased toward this epitope. The authors suggest that this bias may be attributable to a greater accessibility of this epitope after intracellular processing of ESAT-6. The authors report a similar bias in response to immunization with intact ESAT-6.

When this epitope was co-administered with a second ESAT-6 epitope (51-70), the responses were shown to be biased toward this epitope. The authors suggest that this bias may be attributable to a greater accessibility of this epitope after intracellular processing of ESAT-6. The authors report a similar bias in response to immunization with intact ESAT-6.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with macromolecular structures composed of branched peptides supported by an oligomeric lysine core [multiple antigen peptide (MAP) structures]. Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Compared to immunization with free peptide, MAP immunizations induced higher responses. Similar reponses were also shown for IFN-γ release.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: While this epitope was shown to be dominant to a second ESAT-6 epitope also described in the study (51-70), it did not offer significant protection against challenge with virulent Mycobacterium tuberculosis, while epitope 51-70 did. Bacterial numbers were quantified in both the lungs and the spleen. Immunization with ESAT-6, ESAT-6 short-term culture filtrate, or BCG all showed protective effects.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with macromolecular structures composed of branched peptides supported by an oligomeric lysine core [multiple antigen peptide (MAP) structures]. Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Compared to immunization with free peptide, MAP immunizations induced higher responses. Similar reponses were also shown for IFN-γ release.
In similar studies, IL-5 was found to be produced in extremely low amounts. Blocking with a monoclonal anitbody against CD8 had no effect on the size of the responses.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with macromolecular structures composed of branched peptides supported by an oligomeric lysine core [multiple antigen peptide (MAP) structures]. Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: While this epitope was shown to be dominant to a second ESAT-6 epitope also described in the study (51-70), it did not offer significant protection against challenge with virulent Mycobacterium tuberculosis, while epitope 51-70 did. Bacterial numbers were quantified in both the lungs and the spleen. Immunization with ESAT-6, ESAT-6 short-term culture filtrate, or BCG all showed protective effects.
In similar studies, IL-5 was found to be produced in extremely low amounts. Also, blocking with a monoclonal anitbody against CD8 had no effect on the size of the responses.

When this epitope was co-administered with a second ESAT-6 epitope (1-20), the responses were shown to be biased toward the latter epitope (1-20). The authors suggest that this bias may be attributable to a greater accessibility of the 1-20 epitope after intracellular processing of ESAT-6. The authors report a similar bias in response to immunization with intact ESAT-6.

Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Compared to immunization with free peptide, MAP immunizations induced higher responses. Similar reponses were also shown for IFN-γ release.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with macromolecular structures composed of branched peptides supported by an oligomeric lysine core [multiple antigen peptide (MAP) structures]. Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: While this epitope was shown to be subdominant to a second ESAT-6 epitope also described in the study (1-20), it offered significant protection against challenge with virulent Mycobacterium tuberculosis, while epitope 1-20 did not. Bacterial numbers were quantified in both the lungs and the spleen. Immunization with ESAT-6, ESAT-6 short-term culture filtrate, or BCG all showed protective effects.

When this epitope was co-administered with a second ESAT-6 epitope (1-20), the responses were shown to be biased toward the latter epitope (1-20). The authors suggest that this bias may be attributable to a greater accessibility of the 1-20 epitope after intracellular processing of ESAT-6. The authors report a similar bias in response to immunization with intact ESAT-6.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with macromolecular structures composed of branched peptides supported by an oligomeric lysine core [multiple antigen peptide (MAP) structures]. Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Compared to immunization with free peptide, MAP immunizations induced higher responses. Similar reponses were also shown for IFN-γ release.

Mice were infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis for 1 month or 7 months, and responses were assesed at both time points. Positive responses, although very low, were only induced at the highest antigen concentrations tested. Responses were similar to those against ESAT-6 protein. Purification studies showed the response was CD4-specific. In parallel studies of a second ESAT-6 epitope (1-20), this epitope was shown to be subdominant. Similar results were found in ELISPOT assays 2-4 weeks post infection.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Monophosphoryl lipid A (MPL) dimethyl dioctadecylammoniumbromide (DDA)/IL-2 was used as an adjuvant.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: While this epitope was shown to be subdominant to a second ESAT-6 epitope also described in the study (1-20), it offered significant protection against challenge with virulent Mycobacterium tuberculosis, while epitope 1-20 did not. Bacterial numbers were quantified in both the lungs and the spleen. Immunization with ESAT-6, ESAT-6 short-term culture filtrate, or BCG all showed protective effects.
In similar studies, IL-5 was found to be produced in extremely low amounts. Blocking with a monoclonal anitbody against CD8 had no effect on the size of the responses.
